statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Chris Webber had 29 points and 12 rebounds Friday night as the Sacramento Kings cruised past the Denver Nuggets 132-96.
article.headline: All-Star statement? Webber pours it on

images.name: Wallace, Gerald 020201 inline
images.caption: Kings rookie Gerald Wallace shows why he is competing in the dunk contest at All-Star weekend.

article.linkText: Kings rack up 132 points in routing Nuggets
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- Playing like they wanted some rest before a tough road trip, the Sacramento Kings earned some Friday night. Chris Webber had 29 points and 12 rebounds in less than three quarters Friday night as the Kings cruised past the Denver Nuggets 132-96. The victory was the third in a row and 15th in 16 games for the Kings, who have won 18 straight at Arco Arena and own the league's best home record of 25-1. Sacramento meets Minnesota on Sunday for the start of a four-game road trip that features two back-to-back contests. The Kings will play the Nets on Monday, the Celtics on Wednesday and the Wizards the following night. With the Nuggets showing little defensive intensity, the Kings raced out to a 42-31 first quarter lead. Sacramento made its first 10 shots and finished the quarter 15-of-19. "Our game plan was to jump them, show them they had no chance early," Kings center Vlade Divac said. "They are a dangerous team, they have beaten the Lakers at home. We wanted to show our teeth early, then get some rest late." Things worked out precisely that way for the Kings, who own the NBA's best record (35-10). Sacramento, which led the entire game, finished one point shy of the highest total in an NBA game this season. After leading by 20 points at the half, Webber scored 12 points in the third quarter and went to the bench for good with 55 seconds left. The Kings led 103-73 after three periods. "We were obviously very good offensively," Kings coach Rick Adelman said. "We came out and shot so well. We jumped on them and kept them down." Although neither player saw time in the fourth quarter, Mike Bibby scored 21 points and Peja Stojakovic had 20. Bobby Jackson scored 15 points and rookie Gerald Wallace had 11. Raef LaFrentz had 16 points and 11 rebounds for Denver, which has lost 10 straight at Arco Arena. James Posey scored 13, Avery Johnson had 12 and Calbert Cheaney added 11. "They are an explosive offensive team and you can't give them open shots," LaFrentz said. "They are such a handful offensively. They find the open man real well." Webber had 17 points, Stojakovic 15 and Bibby had 12 as Sacramento had a season-high point total for an opening half, leading the Nuggets 71-51. The lead was never under 20 points in the second half as the Nuggets dropped their third straight game and allowed a season-high point total. "That's a buzzsaw," Denver coach Mike Evans said. "They just made every shot they put up. When they're shooting like that they can beat anybody."

Game notes
The Nuggets activated Tariq Abdul-Wahad, who had missed the previous 32 games following arthroscopic surgery on his left knee. ... Sacramento's 42 first quarter points was its second highest this season. The Kings had 45 in the fourth period Dec. 23 against visiting Phoenix. ... Denver point guard Nick Van Exel, the team's leading scorer who wants to be traded, took just one shot in 14 first-half minutes and had a four all game, finishing with a season-low five points and seven assists. ... Stojakovic made all six of his first-half shots.
